ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I strengthened my knowledge of French grammar and vocabulary by learning new verb tenses and vocabulary for a wide variety of situations.
I developed several elementary French grammatical skills and vocabulary.
More in-depth grammar skills building off of 110.
I learned a LOT about French! Mostly grammar things.
My french skills improved tremendously this semester. I gained knowledge both of the structure of the language (grammar, vocab, &c.) and of conversational flow.
I learned written and spoken French at the L2 level. Through the French in Action television program, I learned about some French culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course does a good job of pushing students to learn all modes of French communication (speaking, writing, listening, reading).

I am not a fan of the French-in-action system, and sometimes I felt that it didnt adequately prepare us for the test material. A definite strength was the teacher, Louise, who was absolutely fantastic.
Some strengths would be the passion of the professor! Some weaknesses would probably be the way vocabulary is taught, but I have no way to improve it.
No improvement needed! The course taught just the right amount of material while leaving plenty of time for conversation.
The course is very thorough and comprehensive. It is difficult to catch up once you fall behind.
Excellent course, French is up there with Chinese for best languages to learn at Yale. I wish we had done more speaking in class, but overall I think it's super well-organized

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to deepen their knowledge from French L1 and begin the process of gaining conversational competency.
If you take this class, be prepared for the huge workload.
Absolutely! If you want to continue improving your french, this course will let you do that.

If a person is motivated to learn French, I would recommend this course. The course is fast-paced and ambitious; it's difficult to catch up once you fall behind. You do learn a lot of French--you get all the way to the subjunctive by the end of L2. It's nice that the course meets every day and you get to bond as a class.
Absolutely, super fun language and really well-organized
